publicationStmt.publisher: University of Exeter Digital Humanities Lab

availability.p: The letter transcripts are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. This means that you can use these transcripts providing you acknowledge the Hardy's Correspondents project.
The letter images remain the copyright of Dorset Museum. Please contact the Museum if you would like to reuse any of the letter images.

sourceDesc.p: Compiled from various sources cited in individual entries

listPlace.head: List of Place Names

place.note: A generic reference to America

location.note: Unknown location where Hardy lived for a period.

place.note: Having different names before and afterwards, the building was named "Barnes Theatre" during the 1920s. An adaptation of "Tess" was performed here.

location.note: Cornwall is referred to as Off Wessex.

place.note: Suggested further reading: A Pair of Blue Eyes.
Chelsea Station was renamed Chelsea and Fulham Station on 25th November 1902. It was closed in 1940.
A National Park in the South West of England.
Denchworth was part of Berkshire until the 1974 boundary changes transferred the Vale of White Horse to Oxfordshire.
A borough in north London.
Exeter Cathedral, formally known as the Cathedral Church of Saint Peter at Exeter, is an Anglican cathedral, and the seat of the Bishop of Exeter, in the city of Exeter, Devon, in South West England.

location.note: The Gallipoli Campaign took place in the First World War.

place.note: Higher Bockhampton is a tiny hamlet on the edge of Puddletown Heath containing the woodland cottage where Thomas Hardy was born on 2 June 1840.
Home of May Morris, daughter of William Morris.
The Home Office was located in the main building of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, on King Charles Street, until 1978.
A generic reference to India

listPlace.place:
The Lake District The Lakes; Lakeland
54.491330 -3.100976
A mountainous region in North-West England, also referred to as 'the Lakes'.

place.note: Next to Pilsdon Pen
Fictional landmark on Wessex map.
A wooded fictional region of Wessex. The Hintocks consist of Great Hintock, Kings Hintock, and Little Hintock. See .
Further reading: The Woodlanders.
Various of the letters from Florence Henniker are addressed from The Little Orchard, Shoreham. Henniker moved to this address in 1913.
Max Gate was designed by Hardy himself, and built in 1885.
In 1940, the house was left to the National Trust.

listBibl.bibl: National Trust website for Max Gate

place.note: The family seat of the Strangways family, passing to the 1st Earl of Ilchester by marriage.
Mosterton is a village and civil parish in Dorset, England, situated approximately 3 miles north of Beaminster.

location.note: New Caledonia is an overseas French territory located in the South Pacific.

place.note: Situated at the north end of Marshwood Vale

location.note: Portland Bill is a narrow promontory at the southern end of the Isle of Portland.

place.note: The address of Lina Baumann, a fan of Hardy who wrote to him on 19 January 1926, asking if she could send him matter from a lecture that she gave in Zürich

Skerryvore was on 61 Alum Chine Road, but was destroyed during the Second World War. It was in this house, named after the lighthouse designed by Alan Stevenson, that RLS and Fanny settled for the rest of their stay in Bournemouth.
Stinsford is a civil parish and village or hamlet in southwest Dorset, England, one mile east of Dorchester. The parish includes the settlements of Higher and Lower Bockhampton.
Stourhead House is a Palladian mansion with 18th-century landscape gardens, both open to the public as a National Trust property.
Address of Nina Douglas-Hamilton, Duchess of Hamilton.
The church was restored by Thomas Hardy and it was here that he met his first wife Emma Gifford.
A small road in London, off Oxford Street.
A residence of Florence Henniker.
Headquarters of publishers Smith, Elder co. and address of Hardy's publisher Leslie Stephen.
Wessex was an Anglo-Saxon kingdom in the south of Great Britain, from 519 until England was unified by Æthelstan in the early 10th century.
Office of the League for Prohibition of Cruel Sports
